questions.text: Which of the following condition presents with the characteristic skin lesion seen in this newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lamellar ichthyosis

Explanation:

The image shows a newborn with a taut and glistening membrane, which suggests a diagnosis of colloidion baby, which is a feature of lamellar icthyosis.

  • This disorder is typically inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the TGM1 gene, which encodes the enzyme Transglutaminase 1.
  • This enzyme plays a crucial role in the formation of the epidermal barrier, which is essential for maintaining skin integrity and preventing dehydration.
  • The presentation includes fish-like pasted scales, ectropion, eversion of the lips (known as eclabium, resulting in a fish-mouth appearance), deformed ears, palmoplantar keratoderma, and possible nasal blockage.
  • The scaling is generalized, notably accentuated on lower limbs and flexures.

 

Ichthyosis vulgaris (Option A) is caused by a defect in the filaggrin gene, which results in an alteration of the skin barrier. Dry, scaly skin is present mostly on extensors, while the groin and flexors are spared.

  • Ichthyosis is not present at birth, and it usually develops during the first months of life.
  • It presents with very dry skin associated with atopy, hyperlinear palms, and soles; it increases in winter.

X-linked ichthyosis (Option B) is almost exclusively seen in males due to a defect in the STS (steroid sulfatase) gene.

  • It presents with very fine scaling at birth, and between 2 and 6 months of age, hyperkeratosis develops in the trunk, extremities, and neck, giving it a ‘dirty look.’
  • Flexures are spared in this condition.

Harlequin ichthyosis (Option C) presents with armor-like skin, which can interfere with movement and the ability to drink and breathe, and it is often lethal.

  • Bilateral ectropion and eclabium are present and can also cause auto-amputation of digits. 
  • Death mostly occurs due to respiratory problems.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy presents to the clinic with asymptomatic light brown-colored lesions on his body as shown in the image. On slit lamp examination, pigmented nodules on the iris were noted. What is the most common malignancy associated with this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Optic nerve glioma

Explanation: The brown-pigmented lesions shown in the image are café au lait macules, and the presence of pigmented nodules on the iris, known as Lisch nodules, suggests the diagnosis of Neurofibromatosis type-1(NF-1), also known as Von Recklinghausen's disease.

  • It is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome.
  • The gene for NF-1 is located on chromosome 17 and encodes for neurofibromin.

A diagnosis of NF-1 can be made in an individual with 2 or more of the following

  • >/= 6 cafe au lait macules (> 5 mm in greatest dimensions for prepubertal and > 15 mm in greatest dimension post-pubertal persons)
  • Axillary and inguinal freckles
  • >/= 2 neurofibromas (any types) or 1 plexiform neurofibroma optic glioma
  • >/= 2 Lisch nodules
  • Sphenoid dysplasia, tibial pseudarthrosis, or other distinctive bone lesion
  • First-degree relative with a diagnosis of NF-1
  • Malignancies associated with this syndrome are Optic nerve gliomas and astrocytoma.
  • In NF1, optic nerve gliomas typically present in children and are often associated with specific clinical features such as café-au-lait spots (light brown skin patches), Lisch nodules (pigmented nodules in the iris), and axillary freckling (freckling in the armpits).
  • Other characteristic features of the syndrome include
    • Buttonhole sign: Lesions invaginate when pressed with a finger.
    • Bag of worms: Plexiform neurofibroma has a lot of nerves which feels like a bag of worms.

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) (Option B) is a complication of Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (the VHL gene is located on the short arm of chromosome 3).

  • Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the development of tumours and cysts in multiple organs throughout the body.

 

Acoustic Schwannoma (Option C) is a complication associated with neurofibromatosis type-2, caused by mutations in the NF2 gene located on chromosome 22.

  • In NF2, acoustic schwannomas typically develop bilaterally, a hallmark feature that helps distinguish NF2 from sporadic cases of acoustic neuromas, which usually occur on only one side.

 

Endolymphatic sac tumour (Option D) is strongly associated with Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome, a hereditary disorder caused by mutations in the VHL gene.

  • It can occur bilaterally and is typically benign but can be locally aggressive but one of the less common manifestations of VHL syndrome.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents to the paediatrician with a history of developmental delay, multiple hypopigmented macules on his trunk, and a history of infantile spasms. On examination, he also has facial angiofibroma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tuberous Sclerosis

 

Explanation: The given clinical presentation suggests the diagnosis of Tuberous Sclerosis (TSC), an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome.

 

  • This syndrome is caused by mutations in the genes TSC 1(Chromosome 9) and TSC 2 (Chromosome 16), which encode the proteins hamartin and tuberin, respectively.
  • There are four pathognomic skin lesions associated with this condition:
  1. Ash-leaf macules are characterized by oval or irregularly shaped hypopigmented (lighter than surrounding skin) patches and are accentuated on Wood’s lamp examination.
  2. Angiofibroma, previously misnamed adenoma sebaceum, consists of hyperplastic blood vessels and sebaceous glands in immature hair follicles.
  3. Periungual fibroma (Koenen tumours) emerge from the nail folds.
  4. A Shagreen patch is characterized by thickened, leathery skin and typically appears as irregularly shaped plaques with a rough, raised surface, commonly located on the lower back.

 

 

 

Angiofibroma

Infantile spasms, also known as West syndrome, can occur in infants and young children with tuberous sclerosis complex. .

 

 

Ataxia Telangiectasia (Option A) manifests as progressive cerebellar ataxia, telangiectasias, immune system dysfunction predisposing to recurrent infections, high levels of alpha-fetoprotein in serum, and increased susceptibility to malignancies, particularly lymphomas and leukemias.

  • They also present with telangiectasias (small, dilated blood vessels) which are most commonly seen on the conjunctiva of the eyes but also in other parts of the skin, and photosensitivity.

 

 

 Sturge-Weber syndrome (Option B) or encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis, is a rare congenital disorder caused by a mutation in the GNAQ gene on chromosome 9.

  • It is characterized by port-wine stain (nevus flammeus), typically involving the ophthalmic and maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve, glaucoma, and leptomeningeal angiomas.

 

 Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (Option D) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by mutations in the VHL gene located on chromosome 3.

  • Clinical manifestations include central nervous system and retinal hemangioblastomas, renal cell carcinoma, pheochromocytomas, pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours, endolymphatic sac tumours, and multiple cysts in different organs.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the gastroenterologist with a history of recurrent abdominal pain and episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding. On examination, he has multiple pigmented macules on his lips and oral mucosa. A colonoscopy reveals numerous hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome

Explanation: The history of recurrent abdominal pain with GI bleed and multiple pigmented macules on lips with hamartomatous polyps suggests the diagnosis of Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome, an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by mutations in the STK11 gene located on the short arm of chromosome 19.

 

Gardner Syndrome (Option A) is a phenotypic variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), an inherited condition characterized by the development of numerous adenomatous polyps in the colon, along with extracolonic manifestations such as osteomas, epidermal cysts, fibromas, and dental abnormalities.

 

 Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (Option B) is an inherited genetic disorder characterized by the development of numerous adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum.

 

 Cowden Syndrome (Option C) or multiple hamartoma syndrome, is a genodermatosis linked to mutations in the PTEN gene located on the long arm of chromosome 10.

  • It manifests as multiple benign hamartomas affecting various organs, with mucocutaneous lesions and macrocephaly being characteristic features.
  • Individuals with Cowden syndrome have an elevated risk of developing malignant neoplasms, particularly thyroid, endometrial, or breast cancers.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents to the dermatology clinic with a history of severe sunburns after minimal sun exposure. On examination, numerous freckle-like pigmented patches and atrophic areas were noted on the face and arms. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for the patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Xeroderma Pigmentosum

Explanation: The clinical presentation described in the question is typical of Xeroderma Pigmentosum.

  • It is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from sunlight.
  • It arises due to genetic mutations affecting genes responsible for the nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway.
  • It presents with freckle-like pigmented patches, atrophic areas, and other skin abnormalities in sun-exposed areas.
  • Additionally, patients may experience ocular manifestations such as photophobia, conjunctival injection, and corneal ulcers due to UV-induced damage.
  • Systemic manifestations can include mental retardation and low intelligence.
  • Increased risk of developing skin cancers, including melanoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and basal cell carcinoma, at a young age.

 

 

Vitiligo (Option A) is an acquired depigmentation disorder resulting from the absence of melanocytes in the epidermis, which causes white macules and patches on the body.

 

Gorlin syndrome (Option B) or nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome, is a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the PTCH1 gene, which is involved in the Hedgehog signalling pathway.

  • It is characterized by multiple basal cell carcinomas, along with jaw cysts, skeletal abnormalities, facial deformities, and an increased risk of other cancers like medulloblastoma.

 

Bloom syndrome (Option D) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder caused by mutations in the BLM gene.

  • It presents with short stature, photosensitivity, and characteristic facial features including a long, narrow face and prominent nose, along with other physical anomalies such as micrognathia and cafe-au-lait spots.
  • Increased risk of various cancers, particularly leukaemia and lymphoma, at an early age.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology underlying dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa?

choices.text: Mutations in genes KRT5 and KRT14

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Deficiency of type VII collagen

Explanation:

  • Epidermolysis bullosa (EB) refers to a group of rare genetic disorders characterized by fragile skin that blisters and ulcerates easily with minor friction or trauma and is also known as mechanobullous disease.
  • Dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa is caused by mutations in the COL7A1 gene, which encodes type VII collagen resulting in Subepidermal bulla.
  • Depending on the specific type of DEB and the inheritance pattern of the mutated gene, it can be inherited in an autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive manner.
  • A positive family history is present.
  • Common presenting complaints include blistering, skin fragility, and non-healing wounds disproportionate to mechanical trauma.
  • Diagnosis is made with transmission electron microscopy, immunofluorescence antigen mapping using biopsy specimens, and genetic sequencing to confirm the subtype.
  • Treatment mainly focuses on wound care, prevention of infection, and symptomatic management of skin and mucosal complications.

 

The major forms of EB include:

Level of skin cleavage

EB type

Defective protein

Intraepidermal

EB simplex

Keratin 5 & 14

Intra lamina lucida

Junctional EB

Laminin 332

Sublamina densa

Dystrophic EB

Type VII collagen

Mixed

Kindler syndrome

Kindlin-1

questions.text: A 3-month-old female infant presents with linear streaks of hyperpigmentation along Blaschko's lines on her trunk and extremities. The mother reports that the infant also experienced vesicular eruptions shortly after birth that resolved without scarring. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Incontinentia pigmenti

Explanation: The clinical presentation of linear streaks of hyperpigmentation along Blaschko's lines suggests the diagnosis of Incontinentia Pigmenti, also known as Bloch-Sulzberger syndrome

  • The condition is characterized by X-linked dominant inheritance with a mutation in the NEMO gene.
  • It predominantly affects females while resulting in in-utero lethality in males.
  • Presents in 4 stages:

Stage I

Vesicular

Erythematous vesicular rash at birth

Stage II

Verrucous

Mainly on the limbs

Stage III

Hyperpigmentation

Hyperpigmented streaks and whorls along Blaschko’s lines

Stage IV

Hypopigmentation

Pale, hairless, atrophic linear streaks on the lower extremities

 

  • Extracutaneous features:
  • Alopecia
  • Dental: Peg/cone-shaped crowns
  • Ocular: Retinal neovascularisation
  • CNS: Microcephaly, seizures, motor impairments
  • Treatment is typically symptomatic

 

 

 Hypomelanosis of Ito (Option A) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by hypopigmented streaks, patches, or whorls of skin that follow the lines of Blaschko.

  • These manifestations can appear at birth or in early childhood.
  • It may also be associated with neurological, musculoskeletal, and ocular abnormalities.

Epidermolysis bullosa (Option D) is a group of hereditary skin disorders characterized by blister formation (bulla) in response to minor trauma or friction due to mutations affecting proteins responsible for dermal-epidermal adhesion.

  • Subtypes vary in severity, with symptoms ranging from localized blistering to widespread involvement of skin and mucous membranes.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with persistent, rough lesions on his face. Examination reveals hyperkeratotic papules and plaques with a greasy, crusted appearance, predominantly on seborrheic areas. Nail abnormalities include longitudinal ridging and V-shaped notches. Based on histopathological findings showing acantholysis and dyskeratosis, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Darier’s disease

Explanation: The clinical presentation given in the question suggests Darier’s disease, an autosomal dominant disorder with an ATP2A2 gene defect (chromosome 12) responsible for calcium-bound ATPase type 2.

  • Its onset is typically in childhood, exacerbated during summer and monsoon.
  • It presents as warty, dirty, foul-smelling papules in seborrheic areas like the scalp, forehead, nasolabial folds, retro auricular region, chest, middle of the back, axillae, and groins and they are covered with a crust, causing discomfort and itching (No bulla or vesicles are observed).
  • Nails exhibit alternate longitudinal white and red bands (erythro-leukonychia) with distal notching (V sign).
  • Cobblestone lesions on the palate can be seen.
  • HPE shows suprabasal acantholysis and dyskeratosis, leading to the formation of dyskeratotic cells known as Corps ronds and grains.

 

Hailey-Hailey disease (Option B) or familial benign chronic pemphigus, is an autosomal dominant inherited acantholytic disorder caused by ATP2C1 gene mutation (chromosome 3).

  • It is seen in adolescents, characterized by recurrent vesicular eruptions, primarily in flexures and intertriginous areas, with maceration and a chronic, exacerbating course.
  • No mucosal involvement distinguishes it from pemphigus.
  • Biopsy typically reveals partial suprabasal acantholysis, resembling a dilapidated brick wall appearance.


 

Grover's disease (Option C) also known as transient acantholytic dermatosis, typically presents with sudden onset of pruritic papules predominantly on the trunk of older adults, especially in hot and humid climates.

  • The lesions are usually erythematous and may show central clearing and histopathological examination reveals acantholysis.
  • However, nail abnormalities such as longitudinal ridging and V-shaped notches are not characteristic of Grover's disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male who had recently travelled to Rajasthan presented to the clinic with a complaint of a persistent skin lesion on his right forearm. About two months ago, it initially appeared as a small red bump, but it grew in size and became ulcerated. On examination, the lesion appears to have a raised border with central crusting. The surrounding skin shows signs of inflammation with erythema. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cutaneous Leishmaniasis

Explanation: The characteristic lesion on the forearm, which suggests a recent travel history to Rajasthan, suggests the diagnosis of Leishmaniasis, caused by protozoan parasites transmitted by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies.

  • Old-world cutaneous leishmaniasis, also known as Delhi boil or Oriental sore, is caused by L.major, L.aethiopica, L.infantum, and L.tropica.
  • New world cutaneous leishmaniasis is known as Chiclero ulcer caused by L.mexicana.
  • The skin lesion starts as an erythematous papules that progress into an ulcer.
  • The Annular lesion with central crusting with a history of travel to endemic regions is the classical feature of cutaneous leishmaniasis.
  • Direct microscopy demonstrates amastigotes (round or oval bodies with characteristic nuclei and kinetoplast) in Giemsa‐stained smears from infected skin.
  • Culture in Novy McNeal Nicolle (NNN) media shows the growth of promastigotes.
  • Treatment involves Liposomal amphotericin B and miltefosine.

 

Lyme disease (Option A)

  • Erythema chronicum Migrans is the characteristic rash associated with Lyme disease, which is caused by Borrelia burgdorferi and transmitted by Ixodid ticks.
  • It typically appears as a red, expanding rash with central clearing, resembling a bull's eye or target, and is often accompanied by flu-like symptoms.

Erythema Migrans in Lyme disease

 

Scrub typhus (Option B)

  • It is caused by the rickettsial bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi transmitted to humans by the bite of the larva of trombiculid mites.
  • The bite mark ‘eschar’ is a pathognomonic feature of scrub typhus that occurs at the site of the chigger feeding.
  • It appears as an ulcer that enlarges and undergoes central necrosis to finally turn into a black crust.

 

Cutaneous Anthrax (Option C)

  • Cutaneous anthrax presents 1 to 10 days post-inoculation with a pruritic papular lesion that progresses over several days into a painless ulcer.
  • The lesion may have associated satellite vesicles and will progress into a necrotic and blackened centre with surrounding non-pitting edema.

questions.solution:

Explanation:

  • Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic procedure used to observe fluorescence patterns in the skin under ultraviolet light.
  • It helps identify fungal infections, bacterial infections, pigmentary disorders, and other skin conditions based on characteristic fluorescence reactions
  • This non-invasive test is conducted in a darkened room, emitting light of wavelength 320-450nm.
